articles.headline: Family Net Worth Drops to Level of Early ’90s, Fed Says
articles.snippet: The recent downturn left the median American family in 2010 with no more wealth than in the early 1990s, erasing almost two decades of accumulated prosperity, the Federal Reserve said.
articles.abstract: The recent downturn left the median American family in 2010 with no more wealth than in the early 1990s, erasing almost two decades of accumulated prosperity, the Federal Reserve said.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — The recent economic crisis left the median American family in 2010 with no more wealth than in the early 1990s, erasing almost two decades of accumulated prosperity, the Federal Reserve said Monday.

articles.headline: For Nobel Winners, a Smaller Cash Prize
articles.snippet: The Nobel Foundation announced that it is reducing the size of its prizes by 20 percent, to about $1.1 million from $1.4 million.
articles.abstract: The Nobel Foundation announced that it is reducing the size of its prizes by 20 percent, to about $1.1 million from $1.4 million.

articles.headline: For Ohio Pottery, a Small Revival
articles.snippet: Starbucks helps bring at least a few jobs back to the United States by hiring a plant in East Liverpool, Ohio, to make its new line of coffee mugs.
articles.abstract: Starbucks helps bring at least a few jobs back to the United States by hiring a plant in East Liverpool, Ohio, to make its new line of coffee mugs.
articles.lead_paragraph: EAST LIVERPOOL, Ohio — Not that long ago, this little Ohio River town could call itself the pottery capital of the nation. Some four dozen pottery factories here “set America’s table,” as the locals liked to boast, churning out everything from fine china to chamber pots and employing a large majority of the work force.

articles.headline: Why the Bailout in Spain Won’t Work
articles.snippet: It now appears that the $125 billion bailout of Spain’s banks could make things there worse, not better. And market indicators for the next domino in line for a bailout, Italy, point in the wrong direction.
articles.abstract: It now appears that the $125 billion bailout of Spain’s banks could make things there worse, not better. And market indicators for the next domino in line for a bailout, Italy, point in the wrong direction.
articles.lead_paragraph: It was not enough. And it may never be enough.

articles.headline: Shaky Battery Maker Claims an Advance
articles.snippet: A123 Systems represents the risks of the government’s battery technology program, but it represents its promise with a new technology introduced Tuesday.
articles.abstract: A123 Systems represents the risks of the government’s battery technology program, but it represents its promise with a new technology introduced Tuesday.
articles.lead_paragraph: DETROIT — Lauded during a visit by President Obama, A123 Systems was supposed to be a centerpiece of his administration’s effort to use $2 billion in government subsidies to jump-start production of sophisticated electric batteries in the United States.
articles.byline: By Bill Vlasic and Matthew L. Wald

articles.headline: Vouchers Unspoken, Romney Hails School Choice
articles.snippet: As president, Mitt Romney said, he would seek to overhaul the federal government’s largest school programs into a voucherlike system, replacing top-down Washington mandates.
articles.abstract: As president, Mitt Romney said, he would seek to overhaul the federal government’s largest school programs into a voucherlike system, replacing top-down Washington mandates.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Voucher” is a fighting word in education, so it may be understandable that when Mitt Romney speaks about improving the nation’s schools, he never uses that term.

articles.headline: Heavier Weapons Push Syrian Crisis Toward Civil War
articles.snippet: With evidence that powerful new weapons are flowing to both the Syrian government and opposition fighters, the uprising has thrust the Obama administration into a difficult position.
articles.abstract: With evidence that powerful new weapons are flowing to both the Syrian government and opposition fighters, the uprising has thrust the Obama administration into a difficult position.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — With evidence that powerful new weapons are flowing to both the Syrian government and opposition fighters, the bloody uprising in Syria has thrust the Obama administration into an increasingly difficult position as the conflict shows signs of mutating into a full-fledged civil war.
articles.byline: By Mark Landler and Neil MacFarquhar
